div.p:
Short answer:
Its mostly code (SDK + configs), not a separate hosted Guardrails service you must call.
But some guardrails may internally call models/APIs, so they still consume tokens.

hr.h2: There are two parts to Guardrails
hr.p: This is:

div.class: flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl corner-t-superellipse/1.1

button.class: flex gap-1 items-center select-none py-1

hr.p: So:

blockquote.p:
There is no separate Guardrails API endpoint you call like
POST /v1/guardrails/check

hr.p: You are not calling a hosted Guardrails microservice.

hr.h2: 2. But some guardrails use models under the hood
hr.p: Heres the important nuance.
Guardrails has two types of checks:
hr.h3: A. Local / deterministic checks (no model call)
hr.p: These run purely in code:
These are 100% local, no OpenAI service involved.

hr.h3: B. LLM-based guardrails (these DO call models)
hr.p: These internally make extra model calls:
These will:

li.p: Use OpenAI models (or your configured model endpoint)

There is:
No separate Guardrails SaaS service
No separate Guardrails endpoint
No extra infrastructure you must deploy

hr.p: That is just:
You use it to:

This means:
Guardrails executes inside your infrastructure
You keep architectural control
No extra external dependency

div.p: Yes Google Model Armor is a guardrail-style service, and unlike OpenAI Guardrails (which is mostly SDK code), Model Armor is a hosted cloud service that you enable and integrate with your AI workflows. Google Cloud+1

hr.h2: What Google Model Armor actually is
hr.p: Google Model Armor is a Google Cloud service designed to provide runtime safety and security filtering for AI prompts and responses basically a guardrail layer for LLM systems. Google Cloud
It helps protect against:

li.p: Malicious URLs and security threats in text
Policy enforcement and customizable safety templates Google Cloud

hr.p: So conceptually, its similar to OpenAI Guardrails in purpose both aim to screen prompts and model outputs to enforce safety/security rules.

Hosted service run by Google Cloud
You enable it via:

li.p:
Vertex AI integration
It operates outside your application code as a cloud service
It intercepts and screens prompts/responses and returns sanitized results before the model call or after. Google Cloud+1

hr.p: You configure templates security policies that define what to block, inspect, or allow and then integrate those templates into your Vertex AI inference or use direct REST calls (e.g., sanitizeUserPrompt, sanitizeModelResponse). Google Cloud+1
This means Model Armor runs like a middleware service in your cloud environment.

Not a hosted cloud service
Purely a client-side SDK you run in your own apps environment
It wraps LLM calls and applies checks locally in your code (some checks run locally; others call models as part of the SDK logic). It does not expose a separate cloud endpoint you have to provision or manage. Google Cloud

div.class: flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl corner-t-superellipse/1.1
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2

button.class: flex gap-1 items-center select-none py-1

span.span: Client Your App Model Armor Service (Google Cloud) LLM (Vertex AI or other) Model Armor Service Your App Client

hr.p: Model Armor acts as a cloud safety proxy at runtime.

div.class: flex items-center text-token-text-secondary px-4 py-2 text-xs font-sans justify-between h-9 bg-token-sidebar-surface-primary select-none rounded-t-2xl corner-t-superellipse/1.1
absolute end-0 bottom-0 flex h-9 items-center pe-2

button.class: flex gap-1 items-center select-none py-1

span.span: code) LLM (OpenAI/Azure/etc.) Guardrails SDK Your App Client

hr.p: Guardrails code runs within your application environment.
You can integrate Model Armor in different ways:
Call Model Armors API from your application to screen text before/after model generation. Medium
Model Armor can be configured so that Vertex AI automatically screens prompts/responses without explicit code changes. Google Cloud Documentation
hr.h3: 3. Service Extensions at network or load balancer layer
hr.p: For advanced setups, Model Armor can run via extensions at the infra level, intercepting traffic even before your app processes it. Medium
All of these require enabling and configuring the Model Armor cloud service in Google Cloud.

button.class: hover:bg-token-bg-tertiary text-token-text-secondary my-1 rounded-sm p-1 transition-opacity group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:pointer-events-none group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:opacity-0

hr.p:
Model Armor is a hosted cloud service you enable in Google Cloud.
OpenAI Guardrails is mostly an SDK you embed in code not a separate hosted service.
Both solve similar problems (safety/guardrails), but their deployment models differ significantly.
If you want, I can outline the practical pros & cons for enterprise use of each (e.g., latency, auditability, control, compliance), or visualize how they fit inside a secure LLM architecture.

div.p:
Got it you want a precise, documentation-grounded table, especially focused on Agents + Guardrails.
Below is extracted and structured only from the page youre on (Quickstart + Agents SDK Integration section), not guessed.

hr.h1: OpenAI Guardrails (Agents-focused capabilities)

tr.td: A drop-in replacement for normal Agent
You dont rewrite your agent architecture
Loads guardrails automatically from pipeline config
Input guardrails run on user input; Output guardrails run on agent output
Prevents unsafe prompts and unsafe answers
Prompt Injection Detection applied at tool level
Runs before and after each tool call
Prevents agent tools being hijacked (very important in enterprise agents)
Blocks bad tool calls but lets agent continue and explain error
Better UX (agent can say I cant do that)
Raises exception and stops agent execution
Must append messages only after guardrails pass
If guardrail fails technically, request still continues
If guardrail fails, request is blocked
Example shown with Ollama local model
You can run this with self-hosted models
Shows how many tokens guardrails consumed
Each guardrail exposes its own token usage
You can audit which control is expensive

hr.h1: Specifically for Agents: What happens internally
hr.p: From the documentation text:

blockquote.p: GuardrailAgent automatically configures guardrails from your pipeline:

li.p: Prompt Injection Detection applied at tool level
Other guardrails (PII, Jailbreak, etc.) applied at agent level (input/output boundaries)

hr.p: So actual enforcement points look like this:

hr.p: From what the docs actually show, OpenAI Guardrails for Agents provides:

Tool-level protection against injection
Input/output policy enforcement
Strict vs permissive enforcement modes
Works with Azure OpenAI

Token-level auditability
Drop-in agent replacement
Configurable via UI or JSON
This is not cosmetic. This is real agent governance plumbing.

div.p: Great based strictly on the OpenAI Guardrails Python documentation page you have open, here is a clean, documentation-faithful table focused on what Guardrails offers, especially for agents and real usage (no assumptions added).

hr.h1: OpenAI Guardrails Capabilities (from the official docs)

tr.td: Safety framework for LLM apps that validates inputs and outputs using configurable checks
Guardrails inspects user input and model output automatically
Policies can be defined visually or as config files
Guardrails run automatically on every API call
You dont manually call validation functions
You can audit which guardrails passed/failed
Production ready for real-world LLM apps
Designed for serious applications, not demo-only

button.class: hover:bg-token-bg-tertiary text-token-text-secondary my-1 rounded-sm p-1 transition-opacity group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:pointer-events-none group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:opacity-0

hr.p: Guardrails run in stages:

button.class: hover:bg-token-bg-tertiary text-token-text-secondary my-1 rounded-sm p-1 transition-opacity group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:pointer-events-none group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:opacity-0

hr.p: Docs explicitly say:

blockquote.p: Not all stages are required you can use just input, just output, or any combination.

hr.p: So enforcement is structural, not ad-hoc.
These are the guardrails officially supported:

tr.td: Detects personal data like email, phone
Lets you define your own policy logic

button.class: hover:bg-token-bg-tertiary text-token-text-secondary my-1 rounded-sm p-1 transition-opacity group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:pointer-events-none group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:opacity-0

hr.p: These are not marketing claims they are literally listed in the documentation navigation.

hr.h2: 4. Agent-Specific Capabilities (from Quickstart Agents SDK Integration)
hr.p: This is the most important section for you.

tr.td: Applied at the tool level (before and after each tool call)
Protects tool execution from being hijacked
By default blocks bad tool output but continues execution
Docs warn to only append messages after guardrails pass

button.class: hover:bg-token-bg-tertiary text-token-text-secondary my-1 rounded-sm p-1 transition-opacity group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:pointer-events-none group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:opacity-0

hr.p: This proves that Guardrails is not just moderation it actively protects tool-using agents, which is where real enterprise risk exists.

tr.td: Can run with local / self-hosted models
You can see which control is expensive
Guardrails failure does not block response

button.class: hover:bg-token-bg-tertiary text-token-text-secondary my-1 rounded-sm p-1 transition-opacity group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:pointer-events-none group-[:not(:hover):not(:focus-within)]:opacity-0

hr.h2: 6. What the documentation does NOT claim
hr.p: Important for honesty in architecture reviews.
Guardrails does NOT claim:

li.p: That it is a hosted SaaS service
That it replaces governance or risk teams

hr.p: Everything is positioned as:
You can safely state internally:

blockquote.p: OpenAI Guardrails provides a production-ready SDK that wraps agent execution with structured policy enforcement across input, output, and tool calls, including built-in protections for PII, prompt injection, jailbreaks, hallucinations, and unsafe content, with full developer control and auditability.

page to look atthis is actually a **developer framework**, not a product UI. Let me explain it simply and then connect it to your real-world use (banking, enterprise, agent platforms).\\n\\n---\\n\\n# What this page is about (in simple words)\\n\\n**OpenAI Guardrails (Python)** is a **safety and quality layer** you add around your LLM / agent calls.\\n\\nThink of it like:\\n\\n\u003e *A security + quality checkpoint that sits between your app and the LLM.*\\n\\nSo instead of:\\n```\\nYour App OpenAI model User\\n```\\n\\nYou get:\\n```\\nYour App Guardrails OpenAI model Guardrails User\\n```\\n\\nIt checks both:\\n- what users send **into** the model \\n- what the model sends **out**\\n\\n---\\n\\n# Why this exists (the problem it solves)\\n\\nWithout guardrails, models can:\\n- hallucinate answers \\n- leak sensitive data \\n- accept prompt injections \\n- go off-topic \\n- respond in unsafe ways \\n\\nIn enterprise (especially banking), this is a **huge risk**.\\n\\nSo Guardrails provides:\\n- Safety \\n- Compliance \\n- Predictability \\n- Governance \\n\\n---\\n\\n# The 4 big ideas on the page\\n\\n## 1. \\\"Why Guardrails\\\"\\nMeans:\\n- You can **replace OpenAI SDK with Guardrails SDK**\\n- You dont need to hardcode rules use UI Wizard\\n- You get a structured validation pipeline\\n\\nTranslation:\\n\u003e You get enterprise-level control over model behavior.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## 2. \\\"How It Works\\\"\\nThis is the real architecture:\\n\\n| Step | Meaning |\\n|------|--------|\\n| Configure | Define rules (using Wizard or JSON) |\\n| Replace | Instead of `AsyncOpenAI`, use `GuardrailsAsyncOpenAI` |\\n| Validate | Every request automatically checked |\\n| Handle | You get detailed results about what passed/failed |\\n\\nSo your code becomes:\\n```python\\nclient = GuardrailsAsyncOpenAI(config=\\\"guardrails_config.json\\\")\\n```\\ninstead of:\\n```python\\nclient = AsyncOpenAI()\\n```\\n\\nThats it. Guardrails wraps everything.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## 3. Built-in Guardrails (very important)\\n\\nThese are **prebuilt safety checks** you can turn on:\\n\\n### Content Safety\\n- Moderation (hate, violence, abuse)\\n- Jailbreak detection\\n\\n### Data Protection\\n- PII detection (phone, Aadhaar, email, etc.)\\n- URL filtering\\n\\n### Quality Control\\n- Hallucination detection\\n- Off-topic detection\\n\\nThis is exactly what enterprise AI teams need.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## 4. Guardrails Wizard (visual builder)\\nThe page links to:\\n\u003e https://guardrails.openai.com/\\n\\nThis is a **UI tool** where you:\\n- Click options like checkboxes \\n- Configure policies visually \\n- Export JSON config \\n- Use that config in your code \\n\\nSo non-developers (risk, legal, compliance teams) can define rules too.\\n\\n---\\n\\n# How this relates to *your work* (banking + agent platforms)\\n\\nGiven your background:\\n- You are evaluating OpenAI agent platform for enterprise \\n- Comparing with Google Agentic Platform \\n- Concerned about governance, security, control \\n\\n Guardrails is part of OpenAIs **answer to enterprise governance**.\\n\\nThis directly supports:\\n- \\\"We control what the agent can say\\\"\\n- \\\"We prevent PII leakage\\\"\\n- \\\"We log validation results\\\"\\n- \\\"We ensure compliance rules\\\"\\n\\nThis is similar in intent to:\\n- Googles safety filters \\n- Vertex AI content controls \\n- Dialogflow CX safety layers \\n\\nBut here its:\\n\u003e SDK-level control for developers + UI-level control for governance teams\\n\\n---\\n\\n# Simple analogy (kid-style visual explanation)\\n\\nImagine your AI is a school child \\n\\nWithout Guardrails:\\n\u003e Child answers any question without teacher checking risky\\n\\nWith Guardrails:\\n\u003e Teacher checks:\\n- Is this question safe? \\n- Is the answer correct? \\n- Is the child staying on topic? \\n- Is any private info being shared? \\n\\nOnly then answer goes to the user.\\n\\n---\\n\\n# When would *you* use this?\\n\\nYou would absolutely use Guardrails if:\\n- Youre building internal enterprise agents \\n- Youre exposing chatbot to customers \\n- Youre integrating with banking data \\n- You need auditability + compliance \\n- You need to convince leadership its safe \\n\\n---\\n\\n# If you want, next I can show you:\\n\\nI can explain with diagrams:\\n\\n Show me visually how Guardrails sits inside an enterprise architecture with agents, APIs, UI, and answer: \\n **Its mostly code (SDK + configs), not a separate hosted Guardrails service you must call.** \\nBut some guardrails **may internally call models/APIs**, so they still consume tokens.\\n\\nLets break it clearly.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## There are two parts to Guardrails\\n\\n### 1. The Guardrails framework (this repo)\\nThis is:\\n- A **Python library**\\n- Runs **inside your app**\\n- You install it with:\\n ```bash\\n pip install openai-guardrails\\n ```\\n- You use:\\n ```python\\n GuardrailsAsyncOpenAI(...)\\n ```\\n\\nSo:\\n\u003e There is **no separate Guardrails API endpoint** you call like \\n\u003e `POST /v1/guardrails/check`\\n\\nYou are not calling a hosted Guardrails microservice.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## 2. But some guardrails use models under the hood\\n\\nHeres the important nuance.\\n\\nGuardrails has two types of checks:\\n\\n### A. Local / deterministic checks (no model call)\\nThese run purely in code:\\n- URL Filter \\n- Regex checks \\n- Some PII checks \\n- Some validation rules \\n\\n These are **100% local**, no OpenAI service involved.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### B. LLM-based guardrails (these DO call models)\\nThese internally make extra model calls:\\n- Jailbreak Detection \\n- Hallucination Detection \\n- Custom Prompt Check \\n- Off-topic Detection \\n\\nThese will:\\n- Use OpenAI models (or your configured model endpoint)\\n- Consume tokens\\n- Appear in token usage:\\n ```python\\n total_guardrail_token_usage(response)\\n ```\\n\\nBut this still happens **through the SDK**, not through a separate Guardrails service.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## So the architecture is really:\\n\\n```\\nYour App\\n |\\n |--\u003e Guardrails SDK (local code)\\n |\\n |--\u003e Some checks run locally\\n |\\n |--\u003e Some checks call OpenAI models\\n |\\n |--\u003e OpenAI model (actual generation)\\n |\\nUser\\n```\\n\\nThere is:\\n No separate Guardrails SaaS service \\n No separate Guardrails endpoint \\n No extra infrastructure you must deploy \\n\\n---\\n\\n## What about the Guardrails Wizard UI?\\nThat is just:\\n\u003e A **config generator UI**\\n\\nYou use it to:\\n- Click options visually \\n- Export JSON config \\n- Use that config in your SDK \\n\\nIt does **not** run during production.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## Enterprise implication (important for your evaluation)\\n\\nThis means:\\n Guardrails executes **inside your infrastructure** \\n You keep architectural control \\n No extra external dependency \\n Good for banking / regulated environments \\n But LLM-based guardrails still send text to models (like any LLM call)\\n\\nThis aligns well with:\\n\u003e Governance, security, and control remain with you\\n\\n---\\n\\n## Final verdict\\n\\n\u003e Guardrails is **not a hosted OpenAI service** \\n\u003e It is an **SDK-based enforcement layer**, with optional model-based checks.\\n\\n---\\n\\nIf you want, next I can explain:\\n\\n How this compares to **Googles safety filters vs OpenAI Guardrails** \\n Which gives stronger enterprise control \\n Which one CISOs usually it you want the **full picture**. Heres a complete, structured explanation you can reuse for architecture reviews, leadership discussions, or documentation.\\n\\n---\\n\\n# 1. Is Guardrails a Service or SDK?\\n**Answer: Its an SDK, not a hosted service.**\\n\\n| Aspect | Guardrails |\\n|------|-------------|\\n| Hosted API endpoint | No |\\n| Runs in your infra | Yes |\\n| Installed via pip | Yes |\\n| Uses OpenAI models internally (optional) | Some checks |\\n| Requires separate deployment | No |\\n| Works offline (for non-LLM checks) | Yes |\\n\\nSo architecturally:\\n\u003e You are not outsourcing governance to OpenAI. \\n\u003e You are enforcing governance **inside your own application runtime**.\\n\\n---\\n\\n# 2. Types of Guardrails (Important for Security Teams)\\n\\nThere are **two execution modes** inside the SDK:\\n\\n## A. Local Guardrails (no model call)\\nThese are deterministic checks:\\n\\n| Example | Token usage | Data leaves app? |\\n|--------|--------------|------------------|\\n| URL Filter | 0 | No |\\n| Regex checks | 0 | No |\\n| Some PII detection | 0 | No |\\n| Schema validation | 0 | No |\\n\\nThese are ideal for:\\n- Highly regulated pipelines \\n- Pre-filtering \\n- Data minimization \\n\\n---\\n\\n## B. Model-Based Guardrails (LLM-powered)\\nThese make **extra model calls**:\\n\\n| Guardrail | Calls model? |\\n|--------|----------------|\\n| Jailbreak detection | |\\n| Hallucination detection | |\\n| Off-topic detection | |\\n| Custom prompt evaluator | |\\n\\nThese:\\n- Use your configured model endpoint \\n- Consume tokens \\n- Respect your base_url (Azure, private, etc.) \\n- Still run **under your SDK control**\\n\\n---\\n\\n# 3. Where Guardrails Runs in Enterprise Architecture\\n\\n```\\nUI (Chat / App)\\n \\nBackend (Your API Server)\\n \\nGuardrails SDK (inside backend)\\n Local checks\\n LLM checks (calls model endpoint)\\n \\nOpenAI / Azure OpenAI / Private Model\\n \\nGuardrails post-checks\\n \\nUser response\\n```\\n\\nNothing external added.\\nNo new vendor runtime dependency.\\n\\n---\\n\\n# 4. How this compares with Google Agentic / Vertex AI\\n\\nThis is usually the key enterprise question.\\n\\n## OpenAI Guardrails\\n| Feature | Control |\\n|------|---------|\\n| Enforcement runs | In your app |\\n| Configurable by code | |\\n| Configurable by UI | (Wizard) |\\n| Works with Azure OpenAI | |\\n| Works with Ollama/local | |\\n| Vendor lock-in | Low |\\n| Governance ownership | You |\\n\\n---\\n\\n## Google Vertex AI Safety / Agent Controls\\n| Feature | Control |\\n|------|---------|\\n| Enforcement runs | In Google infra |\\n| Safety filters | Platform-controlled |\\n| Override behavior | Limited |\\n| On-prem portability | Weak |\\n| Auditability | Platform dependent |\\n| Governance ownership | Shared with Google |\\n\\nSimplified:\\n\u003e Google = Platform-enforced governance \\n\u003e OpenAI Guardrails = App-enforced governance\\n\\nCISOs usually prefer:\\n\u003e App-enforced = more controllable, auditable, defensible.\\n\\n---\\n\\n# 5. Why this matters for Banking / Regulated Enterprise\\n\\nGuardrails supports:\\n\\n Defense against prompt injection \\n Blocking PII leaks \\n Preventing unsafe content \\n Preventing hallucinated financial advice \\n Ensuring agent stays within scope \\n Auditability via guardrail_results \\n Token usage visibility \\n Runs within your compliance boundary \\n\\nThis is exactly what regulators ask:\\n\u003e \\\"Where is enforcement applied? Who controls it?\\\"\\n\\nAnswer becomes:\\n\u003e Inside our application, not inside vendor black box.\\n\\n---\\n\\n# 6. Real-world deployment pattern (POC Production)\\n\\nIn serious enterprise systems, teams usually use:\\n\\n- Local guardrails for:\\n - PII\\n - Regex\\n - Structural validation\\n- Model guardrails only for:\\n - Jailbreak detection \\n - Off-topic detection \\n - Complex semantic evaluation \\n\\nBecause:\\n- Cheaper \\n- Faster \\n- More predictable \\n- Less data exposure \\n\\n---\\n\\n# 7. Honest limitations (important for leadership trust)\\n\\nGuardrails does **not** magically:\\n Guarantee zero hallucinations \\n Replace human governance \\n Replace policy engineering \\n Replace red teaming \\n\\nIt provides:\\n Strong enforcement layer \\n Observable safety signals \\n Controllable policy \\n Auditable behavior \\n\\n---\\n\\n# 8. One-line executive explanation\\n\\nIf you need to explain this to leadership:\\n\\n\u003e OpenAI Guardrails is not a hosted service; its a safety enforcement SDK that runs inside our own application, giving us full control over AI governance, compliance, and behavior while still allowing us to use OpenAI or any compatible models.\\n\\n---\\n\\n# If you want next, I can give you:\\n\\nI can create a **clean enterprise architecture diagram** showing:\\n\\n- UI \\n- Agent \\n- Guardrails \\n- Tools \\n- Model \\n- Logging \\n- Audit \\n- Governance \\n\\nYou can directly paste it into:\\n- PPT \\n- Confluence \\n- Architecture review deck \\n\\nJust tell me: \\n *Make me the architecture **Google Model Armor *is* a guardrail-style service, and unlike OpenAI Guardrails (which is mostly SDK code), Model Armor is a *hosted cloud service*** that you enable and integrate with your AI workflows. citeturn0search1turn0search4\\n\\nHeres the breakdown:\\n\\n---\\n\\n## What *Google Model Armor* actually is\\n\\n**Google Model Armor** is a **Google Cloud service** designed to provide runtime safety and security filtering for AI prompts and responses basically a guardrail layer for LLM systems. citeturn0search1\\n\\nIt helps protect against:\\n- Prompt injection and jailbreak attacks \\n- Sensitive data leakage \\n- Harmful or disallowed content \\n- Malicious URLs and security threats in text \\n- Policy enforcement and customizable safety templates citeturn0search1\\n\\nSo conceptually, its similar to OpenAI Guardrails in purpose both aim to **screen prompts and model outputs to enforce safety/security rules**.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## Hosted vs SDK\\n\\n### **Google Model Armor**\\n **Hosted service** run by Google Cloud \\n You enable it via:\\n- Google Cloud Console \\n- gcloud CLI \\n- REST APIs \\n- Vertex AI integration \\n It operates outside your application code as a cloud service \\nIt *intercepts* and *screens* prompts/responses and returns sanitized results before the model call or after. citeturn0search1turn0search3\\n\\n You configure templates security policies that define what to block, inspect, or allow and then integrate those templates into your Vertex AI inference or use direct REST calls (e.g., `sanitizeUserPrompt`, `sanitizeModelResponse`). citeturn0search1turn0search3\\n\\nThis means Model Armor runs like a **middleware service** in your cloud environment.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### **OpenAI Guardrails**\\n Not a hosted cloud service \\n Purely a **client-side SDK** you run in your own apps environment \\nIt wraps LLM calls and applies checks locally in your code (some checks run locally; others call models as part of the SDK logic). It does not expose a separate cloud endpoint you have to provision or manage. citeturn0search0\\n\\n---\\n\\n## Example Architectures\\n\\n### Model Armor (hosted service)\\n```\\nClient Your App Model Armor Service (Google Cloud) LLM (Vertex AI or other) Model Armor Service Your App Client \\n```\\nModel Armor acts as a **cloud safety proxy** at runtime.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### OpenAI Guardrails (SDK)\\n```\\nClient Your App Guardrails SDK (local code) LLM (OpenAI/Azure/etc.) Guardrails SDK Your App Client\\n```\\nGuardrails code runs within your application environment.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## Integration Options for Model Armor\\n\\nYou can integrate Model Armor in different ways:\\n\\n### 1. **REST API integration**\\nCall Model Armors API from your application to screen text before/after model generation. citeturn0search9\\n\\n### 2. **Vertex AI Inline**\\nModel Armor can be configured so that Vertex AI automatically screens prompts/responses without explicit code changes. citeturn0search3\\n\\n### 3. **Service Extensions at network or load balancer layer**\\nFor advanced setups, Model Armor can run via extensions at the infra level, intercepting traffic even before your app processes it. citeturn0search10\\n\\nAll of these require enabling and configuring the Model Armor **cloud service** in Google Cloud.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## Key Differences (at a glance)\\n\\n| Feature | Google Model Armor | OpenAI Guardrails |\\n|---------|-------------------|-------------------|\\n| Hosted service | Yes (Google Cloud) | No |\\n| SDK only | Optional integration | Core |\\n| Integrates natively with Vertex AI | Yes | |\\n| Requires cloud config and templates | Yes | |\\n| Runs inside your application | Optional | Always |\\n\\n---\\n\\n### Summary\\n\\n Model Armor **is a hosted cloud service** you enable in Google Cloud. \\n OpenAI Guardrails **is mostly an SDK** you embed in code not a separate hosted service. \\n\\nBoth solve similar problems (safety/guardrails), but their deployment models differ significantly.\\n\\n---\\n\\nIf you want, I can outline the **practical pros \u0026 cons for enterprise use** of each (e.g., latency, auditability, control, compliance), or visualize how they fit inside a secure LLM architecture.\",{\"_263\":470,\"_478\":644,\"_645\":646,\"_261\":777,\"_778\":100,\"_779\":780,\"_781\":780,\"_104\":401,\"_265\":266,\"_267\":268,\"_269\":268,\"_270\":450,\"_107\":402,\"_67\":24},[471,519,530,540,558,570,586,604,616,633],{\"_472\":473,\"_474\":475,\"_476\":477,\"_478\":479,\"_484\":485,\"_486\":487,\"_488\":-5,\"_27\":489,\"_490\":491,\"_515\":-5,\"_60\":516,\"_517\":-5,\"_518\":-5},\"matched_text\",\"citeturn0search1turn0search4\",\"start_idx\",212,\"end_idx\",244,\"safe_urls\",[480,481,482,483],\"https://cloud.google.com/security/products/model-armor\",\"https://cloud.google.com/security/products/model-armor?utm_source=chatgpt.com\",\"https://docs.cloud.google.com/security-command-center/docs/model-armor-overview\",\"https://docs.cloud.google.com/security-command-center/docs/model-armor-overview?utm_source=chatgpt.com\",\"refs\",[],\"alt\",\"([Google |\\n|------|---------------------------|---------------------------|----------------------------|\\n| Agent Integration | `GuardrailAgent` | A **drop-in replacement** for normal Agent | You dont rewrite your agent architecture |\\n| How to enable | `GuardrailAgent(config=..., name=..., instructions=...)` | Loads guardrails automatically from pipeline config | Governance is applied automatically |\\n| Where guardrails apply | Agent-level boundaries | Input guardrails run on user input; Output guardrails run on agent output | Prevents unsafe prompts and unsafe answers |\\n| Tool protection | Prompt Injection Detection applied at tool level | Runs **before and after each tool call** | Prevents agent tools being hijacked (very important in enterprise agents) |\\n| Other guardrails (PII, Jailbreak, etc.) | Applied at agent boundary | Evaluated on full agent input/output | Protects system prompts, memory, responses |\\n| Tool Violation Handling (default) | `block_on_tool_violations=False` | Blocks bad tool calls but lets agent continue and explain error | Better UX (agent can say I cant do that) |\\n| Strict tool blocking | `block_on_tool_violations=True` | Raises exception and stops agent execution | Needed in banking-grade strict enforcement |\\n| Multi-turn conversation protection | Must append messages **only after guardrails pass** | Prevents polluted memory | Stops poisoned memory attacks |\\n| Fail-Safe mode (default) | `raise_guardrail_errors=False` | If guardrail fails technically, request still continues | Safer for availability |\\n| Fail-Secure mode | `raise_guardrail_errors=True` | If guardrail fails, request is blocked | Safer for compliance-critical systems |\\n| Azure OpenAI support | `GuardrailsAsyncAzureOpenAI` | Same behavior, just different client | Works in enterprise Azure setups |\\n| Third-party models | Works with OpenAI-compatible APIs | Example shown with Ollama local model | You can run this with self-hosted models |\\n| Token tracking | `total_guardrail_token_usage(response)` | Shows how many tokens guardrails consumed | Finance + cost + governance visibility |\\n| Per-guardrail token usage | Each guardrail exposes its own token usage | Available via `response.guardrail_results` | You can audit which control is expensive |\\n\\n---\\n\\n# Specifically for Guardrails]\\n \\nAgent Reasoning\\n \\nBefore Tool Call [Tool Guardrails]\\nTool executes\\nAfter Tool Output [Tool Guardrails]\\n \\nFinal Agent Output [Output Guardrails]\\n \\nUser\\n```\\n\\nThis real usage** (no assumptions added).\\n\\n---\\n\\n# OpenAI Guardrails Capabilities (from the official docs)\\n\\n## 1. Core Framework Capabilities\\n\\n| Area | What the docs say | Meaning in practice |\\n|------|--------------------|---------------------|\\n| Purpose | Safety framework for LLM apps that validates inputs and outputs using configurable checks | Guardrails inspects user input and model output automatically |\\n| Configuration | Wizard (UI) or JSON pipeline | Policies can be defined visually or as config files |\\n| Integration | Drop-in replacement for OpenAI clients | You swap `AsyncOpenAI` with `GuardrailsAsyncOpenAI` |\\n| Execution | Guardrails run automatically on every API call | You dont manually call validation functions |\\n| Observability | `response.guardrail_results` | You can audit which guardrails passed/failed |\\n| Production readiness | Production ready for real-world LLM apps | Designed for serious applications, not demo-only |\\n\\n---\\n\\n## 2. Pipeline Architecture (directly from docs)\\n\\nGuardrails run in **stages**:\\n\\n| Stage | Runs when | Purpose |\\n|------|-----------|---------|\\n| Preflight | Before LLM call | Mask PII, moderation, filtering |\\n| Input | Parallel with LLM | Jailbreak, injection detection |\\n| Output | After LLM generates | Hallucination checks, PII, quality |\\n\\nDocs explicitly say:\\n\u003e Not all stages are required you can use just input, just output, or any combination.\\n\\nSo enforcement is **structural, not ad-hoc**.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## 3. Built-in Guardrails (from documentation menu)\\n\\nThese are the guardrails officially supported:\\n\\n| Category | Guardrail | From docs |\\n|--------|------------|-----------|\\n| Data Protection | Contains PII | Detects personal data like email, phone |\\n| Data Protection | URL Filter | Blocks unsafe or unapproved URLs |\\n| Content Safety | Moderation | Hate, violence, unsafe categories |\\n| Content Safety | NSFW Text | Sexual unsafe content |\\n| Security | Prompt Injection Detection | Detects system override attempts |\\n| Security | Jailbreak Detection | Detects attempts to bypass safety |\\n| Quality | Hallucination Detection | Detects fabricated information |\\n| Quality | Off-topic Prompts | Ensures user stays within scope |\\n| Governance | Custom Prompt Check | Lets you define your own policy logic |\\n\\nThese are not marketing claims they are literally listed in the documentation navigation.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## 4. Agent-Specific Capabilities (from Quickstart Agents SDK Integration)\\n\\nThis is the most important section for you.\\n\\n| Agent Feature | What docs explicitly state | Why it matters |\\n|--------------|-----------------------------|----------------|\\n| GuardrailAgent | Drop-in replacement for Agent | You dont redesign your agent |\\n| Agent setup | `GuardrailAgent(config=..., name=..., instructions=...)` | Guardrails auto-loaded from config |\\n| Prompt Injection for tools | Applied at the tool level (before and after each tool call) | Protects tool execution from being hijacked |\\n| Other guardrails | Applied at agent level (input/output boundaries) | Full protection around agent behavior |\\n| Tool violation handling | By default blocks bad tool output but continues execution | Better UX and resilience |\\n| Strict tool blocking | `block_on_tool_violations=True` | Required for banking-grade enforcement |\\n| Multi-turn protection | Docs warn to only append messages **after guardrails pass** | Prevents poisoned memory attacks |\\n\\nThis proves that Guardrails is not just moderation it actively protects **tool-using agents**, which is where real enterprise risk exists.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## 5. Enterprise Deployment Features explicitly shown\\n\\n| Feature | From docs | Enterprise value |\\n|--------|------------|------------------|\\n| Azure OpenAI support | `GuardrailsAsyncAzureOpenAI` exists | Works in corporate Azure environments |\\n| Third-party models | Works with OpenAI-compatible APIs (Ollama example) | Can run with local / self-hosted models |\\n| Token tracking | `total_guardrail_token_usage()` | Cost visibility for governance teams |\\n| Per-guardrail token usage | Available per guardrail result | You can see which control is expensive |\\n| Fail-safe mode | Guardrails failure does not block response | Availability-first mode |\\n| Fail-secure mode | Guardrail errors raise exceptions | Compliance-first mode |\\n\\n---\\n\\n## 6. What the documentation **does NOT** claim\\n\\nImportant for honesty in architecture reviews.\\n\\nGuardrails does NOT claim:\\n- That it is a hosted SaaS service \\n- That OpenAI runs your policies \\n- That it guarantees no hallucinations \\n- That it replaces governance or risk teams \\n\\nEverything is positioned as:\\n\u003e A **developer-controlled enforcement framework**.\\n\\n---\\n\\n## enforcement across input, output, and tool calls, including built-in protections for PII, prompt injection, jailbreaks, hallucinations, and unsafe content, with full developer control and
